title.narrative: Team of Experts, Conflict Related Sexual Violence 2020-2023
Team of Experts, Conflict Related Sexual Violence 2020-2023

description.narrative: The ToE results framework is based upon and will contribute to the realization of the Agenda 2030 and in particular Goal 16 (peace, justice and strong institutions and Goal 5 (gender equality and empowerment of women and girls). The project outcome for the period of 2020-2024 is "Greater accountability for CRSV through prompt, effective and victim sensitive criminal proceedings carried out in line with international standards". This will be achived through the following three outputs: Output 1, Political will to promote accountability for CRSV at national, regional and international levels enhanced. Target 1: 100% of peace operations mandated for which the Team of Experts has advocated for includion of the promotion of accountability for fonclict-related sexual violence Target 2: 90% of joint communiques and frameworks of cooperation adopted by the respective member states that include a request for ToE technical and operational support. Indicative activities: 1.1: Engage member states including host countries, to promote accountability for CRSV 1.2: Engage international, regional and national mechanisms and bodies to promote accountability for CRSV, including Security Council 1.3:Engage NGOs and CSOs to promote accountability for CRSV. 1.4: Engage colleagues in relevant UN departments, agencies, funds and programmes to promote joint positioning and coordinated approaches to supporting accountability for CRSV. 1.5: Make recommendations on high-level political advocacy by senior UN officials, specifically the SRSG-SVC, and SRSGs in countries hosting UN peace operations 1.6: Contribute to Secretary-General’s reports on relevant countries and thematic issues. Output 2, Technical and operational capacity of national rule of law institutions and actors to address accountability for CRSV enhanced. Target: 2 assessment reports per year on accountability fr conflict related sexual violence prepared by the ToE. Indicative activities: 2.1:Develop concept notes, projects and funding proposals focused on promoting accountability in collaboration with stakeholders and partners to mobilize resources and support and to facilitate linkages with UN and non-UN partners. 2.2: Provide technical, strategic and programmatic advice and support to partners and beneficiaries on relevant policies/legislation, cases, capacitybuilding, institution building, etc. 2.3: Participate in the development of joint communiqués and frameworks of cooperation to ensure the inclusion of justice and accountability elements, as appropriate. 2.4: Participate in the development of implementation plans and action plans for joint communiqués and frameworks of cooperation to ensure the inclusion of justice and accountability elements, as appropriate. 2.5: Organize and undertake assessment missions to identified countries/situations. 2.6: Prepare assessment reports regarding specific countries. 2.7: Conducting follow up missions on the implementation of assessment report recommendations. Output 3, Cooperation, coordination, coherence and knowledge among the range of actors (governments, CSOs, NGOs, United Nations, etc.) working to promote accountability for CRSV enhanced. Target: 2 joint missions with other UN entities, partners or stakeholders. Indicative activities: 3.1: Develop a network of contacts within governments, CSOs, NGOs, United Nations, etc. to facilitate coordination andinformation sharing. 3.2: Track “situations of concern” for CRSV through media, network of contacts, etc. 3.3: Analyze country/situation specific CRSV information, including specific requests by Member States, UN partners,etc. to determine whether the context falls within the ToE mandate. 3.4: Coordinate with relevant national authorities, UN partners, etc. regarding possible engagement in particularcountries/situations. 3.5: Advocate for the implementation of the findings and recommendations of ToE assessments within and outside the United Nations. 3.6: Prepare or contribute to reports, updates, briefings, conferences, etc. at international, regional and national levelsto promote learning on emerging challenges and approaches to promoting accountability for CRSV based on knowledge and experience in particular countries/situations. 3.7: Facilitate experience sharing based on knowledge and experience in particular countries/situations. 3.8: Develop and consolidate policy and guidance tools for promoting accountability for CRSV.

UN Team of Experts on the Rule of Law and Sexual Violence in Conflict har inkommit till Sida med ett programförslag för perioden 2020-2024. Team of Experts (ToE) bildades 2009 efter antagandet av FNs säkerhetsrådsresolution 1888 som särskilt handlar om sexuellt våld i konflikter för att öka den rättsliga kompetensen på området.
Expertgruppen hanteras gemensamt av kontoret för FN:s generalsekreterares särskilda representant för sexuellt våld i konflikt, högkommissariatet för mänskliga rättigheter, avdelningen för fredsinsatser och utvecklingsorganet UNDP. Mandatet bygger på att det finns en politisk vilja då överenskommelser om samarbete knyts mellan värdländerna och generalsekreterarens särskilda representant för sexuellt våld i konflikter. Värdländerna har varit eller riskerar att hamna i en konfliktsituation där sexuellt våld används eller har använts som ett vapen mot befolkningen för att försvaga och förnedra fienden.
Insatsen syftar till att bidra till FNs mål om Hållbar utveckling SDG 16, Fredliga och inkluderande samhällen samt mål 5, Jämställdhet. ToE har som målsättning att skapa större ansvarsutkrävande för konfliktrelaterat sexuellt våld genom rättsprocesser som är snabba, effektiva och lyhörda för offrens behov, utförda i linje med internationell standard. Detta görs genom att: 1) öka den politiska viljan att främja ansvarsutkrävande för konfliktrelaterat sexuellt våld på nationell, regional och internationell nivå; 2) öka teknisk och funktionell kapacitet av nationella rättsinstanser och aktörer för att ta itu med ansvarsutkrävande för konfliktrelaterat sexuellt våld; och 3) öka samarbete, koordinering, koherens och kunskap hos en rad aktörer (regeringar, civila samhällets och icke-statliga organisationer, FN mfl) som arbetar med att främja ansvarsutkrävandet för konfliktrelaterat sexuellt våld.

UN Team of Experts on the Rule of Law and Sexual Violence in Conflict has submitted a program proposal to Sida for the period 2020-2024. The Team of Experts (ToE) was established in 2009 following the adoption of the UN Security Council Resolution 1888, which deals specifically with sexual violence in conflicts in order to increase judicial competence in the field. The expert group is managed jointly by the Office of the UN Secretary-General's Special Representative for Sexual Violence in Conflict, the High Commissioner for Human Rights, the Department for Peace Operations and the UN Development Programme, UNDP. The mandate is based on the premise that there is a political will when agreements on cooperation are concluded between the host countries and the Secretary-General's Special Representative for Sexual Violence in Conflict. The host countries have been or are at risk of ending up in a conflict situation where sexual violence is used or has been used as a weapon against the population to weaken and humiliate the enemy.
The initiative aims to contribute to UN's Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) 16, Peace, justice and strong institutions and Goal 5, Gender Equality.
ToE aims to create greater accountability for conflict-related sexual violence through legal proceedings that are rapid, effective and responsive to the needs of victims, carried out in line with international standards. This is done by: 1) Political will to promote accountability for CRSV at country, regional and international levels enhanced.; 2) Technical and operational capacity of national rule of law institutions and actors to address accountability for CRSV enhanced. 3) Cooperation, coordination, coherence and knowledge among the range of actors (governments, CSOs, NGOs, United Nations, etc.) working to promote accountability for CRSV enhanced.
The total budget for implementing the five-year program is approximately SEK 124.5 million ($ 14.4 million). With the now proposed Side Support of SEK 30 million (corresponding to SEK 3.5 million) and with support from primarily the United Kingdom and Japan, approximately 70% of the total financing for the five-year period is secured.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

title.narrative: Beslut om insats Team of experts 2020-2023

description.narrative: The report consists of various sections: one addressing the out-put indicators and the other more narrative sections specifying country engagements; thematic engagements; knowledge building; and partnerships. A. Out-put indicators Despite Covid-19 challenges, three out of four indicators are met for 2020. Out-put 1: ToE negotiated promotion of accountability and CRSV in 8 peace operations mandates and all cases succeeded. 100% of the joint communiques and frameworks adopted by respective member states included a request for ToE technical and operational support. Out-put 2: Two assessments reports for CAR and DRC were produced. In CAR the focus was on an in-depth analysis of the judicial response to CRSV in order to assess and reflect on challenges remaining for the national judiciary. In DRC the focus was on the effects of the pandemic on the rule of law response in the country, including ccountability for CRSV. Out-put 3: Only one digital missions to Colombia (with the deputy SG) could be attended due to travel resrtictions B. Country engagement There are stated specific objectives; key achievements; assistance and impact and; looking ahead sections for each of the countries where ToE has engagements. Some high lights of results include in summary: - In the Central African Republic (CAR), the Team provided technical and financial support for the national judicial authorities, which led to three convictions for conflict-related sexual violence at the Bangui Court of Appeal. It also supported building the case-tracking capacity in the High Courts of Bangui and Bimbo to strengthen coordination between the national investigative units and relevant jurisdictions. - In Colombia, the Team contributed to the development of a digest of International Standards on the Prosecution and Adjudication of Conflict-Related Sexual Violence, which will support the transitional and ordinary justice systems to address these crimes. - In the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), it provided technical assistance for the investigation, prosecution, and trial of Ntabo Ntaberi Sheka, who was convicted by the Cour Militaire pérationnelle of North Kivu in November 2020. - In Guinea, the Team continued to support the national authorities to advance accountability for the crimes of 28 September 2009. - In Iraq, the Team worked with partners to strengthen the draft bill on reparations for survivors of Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) captivity. This includes ensuring civil society voices in the drafting process and provisions on survivor sensitive delivery of reparations in the legislation. The Bill was enacted outside this reporting period in March 2021, making improvements for survivors and transitional justice. - In Nigeria, the Team contributed to the training of members of the Attorney General’s Office, the Nigerian Institute of Advanced Legal Studies, and the National Judicial Institute, with a view to integrating sexual violence charges into ongoing cases. - In Somalia, the Team prepared a preliminary analysis of the newly presented draft bill on Sexual Intercourse Related Crimes (2020) forming a basis for the United Nations Assistance Mission in Somalia (UNSOM) advocacy around the withdrawal of the draft bill and reintroduction of the Sexual Offenses Bill (2018). - In line with the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in South Sudan, the Team of Experts supported the finalization by the Republic of South Sudan Joint Defence Board of the Action Plan for the Armed Forces on Addressing Conflict-Related Sexual Violence in South Sudan merging the action plans of the South Sudan People’s Defence Forces (SSPDF) and the Sudan People’s Liberation Army in Opposition (SPLA-IO) on conflict-related sexual violence and resulting in prioritised activities and requests for strategic support. A multitude of activities are underpinning these and other results. C. Thematic engagements Policing This area of engagement has resulted in the establishment of the first investigative unit specialized on sexual violence in CAR. The previous police expert, seconded from Sweden, established the capacity building support in this regard and a new experts will be on board, embedded in UNIPOL. Transitional justice ToE has achieved concrete results in either advancing new legislation (such as in Colombia and Iraq); framing measures of reparation while pursuing criminal justice in tandem (as in Guinea); and working with CSOs that provide victims representation and the Congolese government to ensure reparations judgements are paid (ongoing). To ensure that this work is part of the holistic aspect of every assessment the Team of Experts conducts in all contexts, the Team has used 2020 to develop a policy paper on transitional justice that should be concluded in 2021. Transnational crimes - terrorism and trafficking in persons While terrorism and trafficking in persons continued to be increasingly documented in 2020, the absence of judicial response has resulted in a significant and concerning impunity gap. Acknowledging this challenge, in 2020 the Team of Experts has initiated a comprehensive research mapping the legal and judicial response provided to conflict-related sexual violence committed in the context of terrorism in key situations, identifying gaps, opportunities and specific recommendations that should allow the relevant actors – Member States, national, regional, and international organisations – to address it. The findings of this analysis will shape discussions with relevant partners and Member States in 2021 and the Team’s engagement. D. Knowledge building ToE has considerably strengthened its visibility strategy with a digital dialogue series - reaching more than 3000 viewers with four webinars in 2020. ToE reports that its analysis shows that it has also resulted in creating a small community of practitioners with the same viewers regularly following the webinar and the quality of the series, including, its technical added-value to practitioners pursuing accountability for conflict-related sexual violence has been praised. ToE also collaborated with the Journal of international criminal justice on a Special Issue on Justice and Accountability for Sexual Violence in Conflict: Progress and Challenges in National Efforts to Address Impunity. The Special Issue which brings together 14 articles from leading practitioners and scholars on a range of settings on conflict-related sexual violence represents a landmark publication in the field of accountability for CRSV. E. Partnerships The co-lead entity set-up itself (UNDP, OHCHR, Office of the SRSG-SVC and DPO) creates a foundation of partnerships to the ToE facility. Within the UN this enhances coherence and coordination, including towards the human rights mechanisms, CEDAW, UN Global Focal Point for Rule of Law etc. Some results includes ToE engagement to facilitate: - The signature of a framework cooperation between the Office of SRSG-SVC and the Committee on the Rights of the Child to protect and promote the rights of children affected by, or at risk of, conflict-related sexual violence. - Collaboration between several mandate holders (the Independent Experts on the situation of human rights in the CAR and Somalia and the Special Rapporteurs on trafficking in persons, especially women and children) for the the promotion and protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms while countering terrorism. - Framework of Cooperation aiming at promoting and facilitating the engagement of parliamentarians in addressing conflict-related sexual violence, including in terms of legislation, oversight, budget allocation and advocacy through an intergovernmental engagement with the Inter-Parliamentary Union and the Office of the SRSG-SVC’s. - Deepened cooperation with academia, for example four prominent universities (as above above) for a digital seminar series and academic papers, to deepen the analysis of specific topics related to the national judicial response to CRSV.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
